title: Roberto Scarone
text:
Roberto Scarone Rivera (16 July 1917 – 25 April 1994) was an <a href="Uruguay">Uruguay</a>an <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and manager. He is mainly known for his successful managing spell at the helm of the Uruguayan powerhouse <a href="C.A.%20Pe%C3%B1arol">Peñarol</a> in the early 1960s.
Career.
Scarone started playing professionally at his hometown club Peñarol in the 1930s. In 1939, at the age of 22, he moved to <a href="Club%20de%20Gimnasia%20y%20Esgrima%20La%20Plata">Gimnasia La Plata</a> in Argentina where he spent four seasons. Between 1943 and 1947 he had spells with Mexican sides <a href="Club%20Am%C3%A9rica">América</a> and <a href="Atlante%20F.C.">Atlante</a> before coming back to Gimnasia in 1948. That same year he retired from active football and immediately took over as the club's coach.
His then spent the following three decades coaching a number of South American clubs in Argentina, Colombia, Chile, Peru, and Mexico. His greatest successes came in the early 1960s with Peñarol with whom he won three consecutive <a href="Uruguayan%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Uruguayan championships</a> in 1959, 1960 and 1961, two <a href="Copa%20Libertadores">Copa Libertadores</a> titles (in 1960 and 1961) and the 1961 <a href="Intercontinental%20Cup%20%28football%29">Intercontinental Cup</a>. On account of his success with Peñarol he was made a member of the <a href="Uruguay%20national%20football%20team">Uruguay national football team</a> coaching staff in the <a href="1962%20FIFA%20World%20Cup">1962 FIFA World Cup</a>, along with <a href="Juan%20Carlos%20Corazzo">Juan Carlos Corazzo</a>, <a href="Juan%20L%C3%B3pez%20Fontana">Juan López Fontana</a> and <a href="Hugo%20Bagnulo">Hugo Bagnulo</a>.
He also had considerable success coaching in Peru, winning four <a href="Peruvian%20Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n">Peruvian championships</a> with <a href="Centro%20Ique%C3%B1o">Centro Iqueño</a> and <a href="Universitario%20de%20Deportes">Universitario de Deportes</a>, and even took Universitario to the finals of the <a href="1972%20Copa%20Libertadores">1972 Copa Libertadores</a>. In addition, he won the <a href="Primera%20Divisi%C3%B3n%20de%20M%C3%A9xico%201965%E2%80%9366">1965–66 Mexican championship</a> with <a href="Club%20Am%C3%A9rica">Club América</a>. He also had a brief stint managing <a href="Peru%20national%20football%20team">Peru national football team</a> in the <a href="1974%20FIFA%20World%20Cup%20qualification%20%28CONMEBOL%29">1974 FIFA World Cup qualifying campaign</a>.
Scarone retired from coaching in 1982. After suffering from <a href="Alzheimer%27s%20disease">Alzheimer's disease</a> in his later years, Scarone died on 25 April 1994 in his hometown of Montevideo.
